Running test case 13: Print files opened events by process


Output will be saved to: few_shot_3trails_and_smt.json
input prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Print files opened events by process


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

```

```

```

} interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }\n```\n\nTrace disk size by process:\n```\ntracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }\n```\n\nCount page faults by process\n```\nsoftware:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }\n```\n\nCount LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):\n```\nhardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }\n```\n\nProfile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:\n```\nprofile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }\n```\n\nFiles opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2\n```\ntracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }\n```\n\ntcp connect events with PID and process name\n```\nkprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Count LLC cache misses by process name


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Count LLC cache misses by process name

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

```
 hardware:cache-misses:1000000 {@[comm, pid]=count()}
```

[run_bpftrace_prog_with_function_call]:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Count LLC cache misses by process name


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other

Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

following user request: Count LLC cache misses by process name


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }

```

```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

```

```

```

```

```

```

```

```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

```

```

```

trace processes calling sleep:
```

```

count syscalls by process name:
```

```

```

```

```

```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

```

```

```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

```

}\n```\n\nCount LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):\n```\nhardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }\n```\n\nProfile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:\n```\nprofile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }\n```\n\nFiles opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2\n```\ntracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }\n```\n\ntcp connect events with PID and process name\n```\nkprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace directory entry cache (dcache) lookups by process


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Trace directory entry cache (dcache) lookups by process

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace directory entry cache (dcache) lookups by process


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace directory entry cache (dcache) lookups by process


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }

[run_bpftrace_prog_with_function_call]:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace directory entry cache (dcache) lookups by process


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace md flush events with pid and process name


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

[run_bpftrace_prog_with_function_call]:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace md flush events with pid and process name


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Running test case 19: Print CPU scheduler run queue latency as a histogram


Output will be saved to: few_shot_3trails_and_smt.json
input prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Print CPU scheduler run queue latency as a histogram


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

regenerated program:
 c
#include <linux/ptrace.h>
#include <uapi/linux/bpf.h>
#include "assume.h"

struct key_t {
    u32 pid;
};
BPF_HASH(start, struct request *);
BPF_ARRAY(pid, u32, 10);

int trace_entry(void *ctx) {
    // Start of execution
    struct task_struct *current = (struct task_struct *)bpf_get_current_task();
    u32 pid = current->pid;
    u64 ts = bpf_ktime_get_ns();
    start.update(&pid, &ts);
    return 0;
}

int trace_return(void *ctx) {
    // End of execution
    struct task_struct *current = (struct task_struct *)bpf_get_current_task();
    u32 pid = current->pid;
    u64 *value;
    value = start.lookup(&pid);
    ASSERT(value != NULL);
    u64 delta = bpf_ktime_get_ns() - *value;
    pid.increment(delta / 1000);
    return 0;
}

#include <linux/ptrace.h>

c
#include <linux/ptrace.h>
#include <uapi/linux/bpf.h>
#include "assume.h"

struct key_t {
    u32 pid;
};
BPF_HASH(start, struct request *);
BPF_ARRAY(pid, u32, 10);

int trace_entry(void *ctx) {
    // Start of execution
    struct task_struct *current = (struct task_struct *)bpf_get_current_task();
    u32 pid = current->pid;
    u64 ts = bpf_ktime_get_ns();
    start.update(&pid, &ts);
    return 0;
}

int trace_return(void *ctx) {
    // End of execution
    struct task_struct *current = (struct task_struct *)bpf_get_current_task();
    u32 pid = current->pid;
    u64 *value;
    value = start.lookup(&pid);
    ASSERT(value != NULL);
    u64 delta = bpf_ktime_get_ns() - *value;
    pid.increment(delta / 1000);
    return 0;
}

 c
#include <linux/ptrace.h>
#include <uapi/linux/bpf.h>
#include "assume.h"

struct key_t {
    u32 pid;
};
BPF_HASH(start, struct request *);
BPF_ARRAY(pid, u32, 10);

int trace_entry(void *ctx) {
    // Start of execution
    struct task_struct *current = (struct task_struct *)bpf_get_current_task();
    u32 pid = current->pid;
    u64 ts = bpf_ktime_get_ns();
    start.update(&pid, &ts);
    return 0;
}

int trace_return(void *ctx) {
    // End of execution
    struct task_struct *current = (struct task_struct *)bpf_get_current_task();
    u32 pid = current->pid;
    u64 *value;
    value = start.lookup(&pid);
    ASSERT(value != NULL);
    u64 delta = bpf_ktime_get_ns() - *value;
    pid.increment(delta / 1000);
    return 0;
}

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Print CPU scheduler run queue latency as a histogram


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Print CPU scheduler run queue latency as a histogram

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

}

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Print CPU scheduler run queue latency as a histogram


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

```

```

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Summarizes CPU scheduler run queue length as a histogram


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Summarizes CPU scheduler run queue length as a histogram

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

following user request: Summarizes CPU scheduler run queue length as a histogram


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Summarizes CPU scheduler run queue length as a histogram

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

```

}

You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Summarizes CPU scheduler run queue length as a histogram


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

input prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: List new thread creation with pid and thread identifies


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

compile_bpftrace_with_retry
['printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\\n", pid, tid)']

['kprobe:clone { printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\\n", pid, tid) }']
0 kprobe:clone { printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\n", pid, tid) }
prompts
 
    I will assign you the job I have a function clone { printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\n", pid, tid) } like , please provide me with the function definition and the corresponding argument to be assigned to arg0. I need the output only has the variable name without the type info. I want the result in the below text format :
    
    ```text
    And we know the definition of {function} is {function definition}, we should put all the first argument {the first argument}'s operation as to arg0, the second argument {the second argument} be arg1, the third argument {the third argument} be arg2, {.. until the end of argument list}. You should replace the following paremeter with corresponding one.
    ```
    
text code ['And we know the definition of clone is void clone(int pid, int tid) { printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\\n", pid, tid) }, we should put all the first argument pid\'s operation as to arg0, the second argument tid be arg1. You should replace the following parameter with the corresponding one.']

kprobe prompts
 
    I'm working on a project involving writing bpftrace programs 
    and I just got the job of 
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: List new thread creation with pid and thread identifies


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

, in my coded program:
    "kprobe:clone { printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\n", pid, tid) }" 
    line 0, kprobe:clone { printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\n", pid, tid) }, I need to verify based on the context of what I ask, 
    can you provide some refined constraints information on this line 
    considering the context. 
    
    You should generate the refined constraints in following C format:
    ```c
      assume([]);
      sassert([]);
    ```
    The requirement is to put the pre condition to the correstponding [] which assume will be inserted in line 2, sassert will be inserted in the end of the function kprobe:clone { printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\n", pid, tid) } and should comply the c definitoin so that all the variable is defined in the context and should pass bpftrace compiler. You only need to provide the pre condition in one line and post condition in one line if there are multiple of them you should use & to connect them.
    And we know the definition of clone is void clone(int pid, int tid) { printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\n", pid, tid) }, we should put all the first argument pid's operation as to arg0, the second argument tid be arg1. You should replace the following parameter with the corresponding one.

kprobe responses Based on the context you provided, the clone function is used to create a new thread and it takes two arguments: pid and tid. The pid is the process identifier and tid is the thread identifier. 

In the context of bpftrace, the arguments are referred to as arg0 and arg1 respectively. 

Here is a possible refinement of the constraints in C format:

```c
assume(arg0 > 0 & arg1 > 0);
sassert(arg0 != arg1);
```

In the above code, the `assume` function is used to specify the precondition that both pid (arg0) and tid (arg1) should be greater than 0. This is because pid and tid are always positive integers in a Unix-like system.

The `sassert` function is used to specify the postcondition that pid (arg0) and tid (arg1) should not be equal. This is because in a Unix-like system, each thread has a unique identifier.
assume(arg0 > 0 & arg1 > 0);
sassert(arg0 != arg1); 



kprobe_matches, after get_kprobe_prompt program:
 kprobe:clone { printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\n", pid, tid) }
compile_bpftrace_with_retry

start verify with z3: 


retry_generate_bpftrace_program_for_sat
 
The bpftrace program below is use to 
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: List new thread creation with pid and thread identifies


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```



kprobe:clone { printf("New Thread Created! PID=%d TID=%d\n", pid, tid) }

kfunc:btrfs:btrfs_discard_schedule_work
kfunc:btrfs:btrfs_schedule_zone_finish_bg
kfunc:cfg80211:__cfg80211_stop_sched_scan
kfunc:cfg80211:__traceiter_cfg80211_sched_scan_results
kfunc:cfg80211:__traceiter_cfg80211_sched_scan_stopped
kfunc:cfg80211:__traceiter_rdev_sched_scan_start

You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: List new thread creation with pid and thread identifies


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

following user request: List new thread creation with pid and thread identifies


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

```

```

You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: List new thread creation with pid and thread identifies


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

regenerated program:
 bash
#include <uapi/linux/ptrace.h>
#include <uapi/linux/bpf_perf_event.h>

struct exit_reason {
    u64 reason;
};

struct key_type {
    int pid;
};

struct value_type {
    int count;
};

BPF_HASH(counts, struct key_type, struct value_type);
BPF_HASH(exits, struct exit_reason, counts);

int kprobe__kvm_handle_exit(struct pt_regs *ctx) {
    // Get the PID of the process
    u32 pid = bpf_get_current_pid_tgid();
    
    // Create a new entry for this PID if necessary
    struct key_type key = { .pid = pid };
    if (!counts.lookup(&key)) {
        counts.insert(&key, &value_type { .count = 1 });
    } else {
        counts.increment(&key);
    }

    // Increment the counter for the current exit reason
    struct exit_reason exit_reason = { .reason = ctx->rax };
    exits.increment(&exit_reason);

    return 0;
}
compile_bpftrace_with_retry

#include <uapi/linux/ptrace.h>
#include <uapi/linux/bpf_perf_event.h>

struct exit_reason {
    u64 reason;
};

struct key_type {
    int pid;
};

struct value_type {
    int count;
};

BPF_HASH(counts, struct key_type, struct value_type);
BPF_HASH(exits, struct exit_reason, counts);

int kprobe__kvm_handle_exit(struct pt_regs *ctx) {
    // Get the PID of the process
    u32 pid = bpf_get_current_pid_tgid();
    
    // Create a new entry for this PID if necessary
    struct key_type key = { .pid = pid };
    if (!counts.lookup(&key)) {
        counts.insert(&key, &value_type { .count = 1 });
    } else {
        counts.increment(&key);
    }

    // Increment the counter for the current exit reason
    struct exit_reason exit_reason = { .reason = ctx->rax };
    exits.increment(&exit_reason);

    return 0;
}

You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Display the exit_reason and its statistics of each vm exit in kvm


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Display the exit_reason and its statistics of each vm exit in kvm


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Display the exit_reason and its statistics of each vm exit in kvm

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

Run the bpftrace program
```
 BEGIN
{
@exit_reasons = map();
}

kprobe:kvm_handle_exit {
$exit_reason = $regs->rax;
@exit_reasons[$exit_reason]++;
}

END
{
printf("Exit Reason Statistics\n");
foreach($key, $val in @exit_reasons)
{
printf("\t%s : %d\n", $key, $val);
}
}
```
with the following error and ouput:
```
stdin:3:17-20: ERROR: Unknown function: map
@exit_reasons = map();
                ~~~

```
This is your trail 1 out of 3 trails.

And fix the error.

following user request: Display the exit_reason and its statistics of each vm exit in kvm

```

```

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace mount and umount syscalls system-wide and print with pid


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Trace mount and umount syscalls system-wide and print with pid

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

}\n```\n\nFiles opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2\n```\ntracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }\n```\n\ntcp connect events with PID and process name\n```\nkprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }\n```\n\n\nYou can refer to the above examples and hints to\nwrite your own bpftrace program to help user with:\n\nTrace mount and umount syscalls system-wide and print with pid\n\nUse a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.\nNo explain and no instructions. error  stdin:1:50-54: ERROR: The args builtin can only be used with tracepoint/kfunc/uprobeprobes (kprobe used here)
kprobe:do_mount { printf("Mounted device=%ld\n", args->dev)}

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace mount and umount syscalls system-wide and print with pid


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Trace mount and umount syscalls system-wide and print with pid

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

Run the bpftrace program
```
 kprobe:mount { printf("Mounted device=%s\n", arg1) }
	kprobe:umount { printf("Unmounted device=%s\n", arg1) }
```
with the following error and ouput:
```
stdin:1:1-13: WARNING: mount is not traceable (either non-existing, inlined, or marked as "notrace"); attaching to it will likely fail
kprobe:mount { printf("Mounted device=%s\n", arg1) }
~~~~~~~~~~~~
stdin:1-2: WARNING: umount is not traceable (either non-existing, inlined, or marked as "notrace"); attaching to it will likely fail
stdin:1:16-51: ERROR: printf: %s specifier expects a value of type string (integer supplied)
kprobe:mount { printf("Mounted device=%s\n", arg1) }
               ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
stdin:2:18-55: ERROR: printf: %s specifier expects a value of type string (integer supplied)
    kprobe:umount { printf("Unmounted device=%s\n", arg1) }
                    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

```
This is your trail 1 out of 3 trails.

And fix the error.

```
with the following error and ouput:

[run_bpftrace_prog_with_function_call]:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace mount and umount syscalls system-wide and print with pid


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

    ```text
    And we know the definition of {function} is {function definition}, we should put all the first argument {the first argument}'s operation as to arg0, the second argument {the second argument} be arg1, the third argument {the third argument} be arg2, {.. until the end of argument list}.     ```
    
text code ['And we know the definition of bpf_jit_compile is bpf_jit_compile { printf("bpf jit compiled");}, but there are no arguments in this function to be assigned to arg0, arg1, arg2, etc.']

kprobe prompts
 
    I'm working on a project involving writing bpftrace programs 
    and I just got the job of 
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace bpf jit compile events


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

, in my coded program:
    "kprobe:bpf_jit_compile { printf("bpf jit compiled");}" 
    line 0, kprobe:bpf_jit_compile { printf("bpf jit compiled");}, I need to verify based on the context of what I ask, 
    can you provide some refined constraints information on this line 
    considering the context. 
    
    You should generate the refined constraints in following C format:
    ```c
      assume([]);
      sassert([]);
    ```
    The requirement is to put the pre condition to the correstponding [] which assume will be inserted in line 2, sassert will be inserted in the end of the function kprobe:bpf_jit_compile { printf("bpf jit compiled");} and should comply the c definitoin so that all the variable is defined in the context and should pass bpftrace compiler. You only need to provide the pre condition in one line and post condition in one line if there are multiple of them you should use & to connect them.
    And we know the definition of bpf_jit_compile is bpf_jit_compile { printf("bpf jit compiled");}, but there are no arguments in this function to be assigned to arg0, arg1, arg2, etc.

The constraints you need would depend on the specific requirements of your project and the behavior you expect from the bpf_jit_compile function. However, I can suggest that you might want to consider constraints related to the state of the system when the function is called, the expected output of the function, and any side effects the function might have.

```

```

```

```

```

```

```

```

Running test case 26: Trace btrfs operations system-wide


Output will be saved to: few_shot_3trails_and_smt.json
input prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace btrfs operations system-wide


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

}\n```\n\ncount syscalls by process name:\n```\ntracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }\n```\n\nFiles opened by process:\n```\ntracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }\n```\n\nRead size distribution by process:\n```\ntracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }\n```\n\nShow per-second syscall rates:\n```\ntracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }\n```\n\nTrace disk size by process:\n```\ntracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }\n```\n\nCount page faults by process\n```\nsoftware:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }\n```\n\nCount LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):\n```\nhardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }\n```\n\nProfile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:\n```\nprofile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }\n```\n\nFiles opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2\n```\ntracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }\n```\n\ntcp connect events with PID and process name\n```\nkprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace btrfs operations system-wide


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Trace btrfs operations system-wide

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

Run the bpftrace program
```
 tracepoint:btrfs:transaction_start{printf("Started transaction ID: %llu\n", args->transid)}
```
with the following error and ouput:
```
stdin:1:1-35: ERROR: tracepoint not found: btrfs:transaction_start
tracepoint:btrfs:transaction_start{printf("Started transaction ID: %llu\n", args->transid)}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

```
This is your trail 1 out of 3 trails.
Please retry generating the bpftrace program for: Trace btrfs operations system-wide
And fix the error.



[run_bpftrace_prog_with_function_call]:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace btrfs operations system-wide


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Trace btrfs operations system-wide

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

```

```

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace btrfs operations system-wide


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other

Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

[run_bpftrace_prog_with_function_call]:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Trace btrfs operations system-wide


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

following user request: Trace btrfs operations system-wide

```
