full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Counts swapins by process, to show which process is affected by swapping


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Counts swapins by process, to show which process is affected by swapping

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

Run the bpftrace program
```
 tracepoints:vm:pagefault_user { @[comm] = count(); }
```
with the following error and ouput:
```
FATAL: Invalid probe type made it to attachpoint parser
timeout: the monitored command dumped core

```
This is your trail 1 out of 3 trails.
Please retry generating the bpftrace program for: Counts swapins by process, to show which process is affected by swapping
And fix the error.

```
 tracepoints:vm:pagefault_user{@[comm]=count()}
```
with the following error and ouput:
```
FATAL: Invalid probe type made it to attachpoint parser
timeout: the monitored command dumped core

```
This is your trail 2 out of 3 trails.
Please retry generating the bpftrace program for: Counts swapins by process, to show which process is affected by swapping
And fix the error.



[run_bpftrace_prog_with_function_call]:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Counts swapins by process, to show which process is affected by swapping


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Counts swapins by process, to show which process is affected by swapping

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

```
 tracepoints:vm:pagefault_user { @[comm] = count(); }
```

```
timeout: the monitored command dumped core

```

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Counts swapins by process, to show which process is affected by swapping


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: Counts swapins by process, to show which process is affected by swapping


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

Running test case 38: traces the kernel function performing active TCP connections(eg, via a connect() syscall; accept() are passive connections).

input prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: traces the kernel function performing active TCP connections(eg, via a connect() syscall; accept() are passive connections).


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

prompts
 
    I will assign you the job I have a function tcp_connect{printf("Connected from PID %d, Comm %s\n", pid, comm)} like , please provide me with the function definition and the corresponding argument to be assigned to arg0. I need the output only has the variable name without the type info. I want the result in the below text format :
    
    ```text
    And we know the definition of {function} is {function definition}, we should put all the first argument {the first argument}'s operation as to arg0, the second argument {the second argument} be arg1, the third argument {the third argument} be arg2, {.. until the end of argument list}. You should replace the following paremeter with corresponding one.
    ```
    
text code ['And we know the definition of tcp_connect is tcp_connect{printf("Connected from PID %d, Comm %s\\n", pid, comm)}, we should put all the first argument pid\'s operation as to arg0, the second argument comm be arg1. You should replace the following parameter with the corresponding one.']

kprobe prompts
 
    I'm working on a project involving writing bpftrace programs 
    and I just got the job of 
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: traces the kernel function performing active TCP connections(eg, via a connect() syscall; accept() are passive connections).


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

, in my coded program:
    "kprobe:tcp_connect{printf("Connected from PID %d, Comm %s\n", pid, comm)}" 
    line 0, kprobe:tcp_connect{printf("Connected from PID %d, Comm %s\n", pid, comm)}, I need to verify based on the context of what I ask, 
    can you provide some refined constraints information on this line 
    considering the context. 
    
    You should generate the refined constraints in following C format:
    ```c
      assume([]);
      sassert([]);
    ```
    The requirement is to put the pre condition to the correstponding [] which assume will be inserted in line 2, sassert will be inserted in the end of the function kprobe:tcp_connect{printf("Connected from PID %d, Comm %s\n", pid, comm)} and should comply the c definitoin so that all the variable is defined in the context and should pass bpftrace compiler. You only need to provide the pre condition in one line and post condition in one line if there are multiple of them you should use & to connect them.
    And we know the definition of tcp_connect is tcp_connect{printf("Connected from PID %d, Comm %s\n", pid, comm)}, we should put all the first argument pid's operation as to arg0, the second argument comm be arg1. You should replace the following parameter with the corresponding one.

kprobe responses Based on your requirements, here's a possible way to define the preconditions and postconditions for your bpftrace program:

```c
assume(arg0 >= 0 & arg1 != NULL);
sassert(arg0 >= 0 & arg1 != NULL);
```

In the precondition, we're assuming that the process ID (`arg0`) is a non-negative integer, as process IDs are always non-negative in a Unix-like system. We're also assuming that the command name (`arg1`) is not NULL, as every process should have a command name.

In the postcondition, we're asserting the same conditions. This means that after the `kprobe:tcp_connect` function is executed, the process ID should still be a non-negative integer and the command name should still not be NULL. These conditions should always hold true if the function is working correctly.
assume(arg0 >= 0 & arg1 != NULL);
sassert(arg0 >= 0 & arg1 != NULL);

 kprobe:tcp_connect{printf("Connected from PID %d, Comm %s\n", pid, comm)}

The bpftrace program below is use to 
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: traces the kernel function performing active TCP connections(eg, via a connect() syscall; accept() are passive connections).


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

input prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

[retry]: left:  2
error  stdin:1:1-34: ERROR: tracepoint not found: xfs:xfs_file_read_done
tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_read_done { @["read"] = hist(args->delta_ns); }
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~




full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

Run the bpftrace program
```
 tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_read_done { @["read"] = hist(args->delta_us); }
	tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_write_done { @["write"] = hist(args->delta_us); }
	tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_open_done { @["open"] = hist(args->delta_us); }
	tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_fsync_done { @["fsync"] = hist(args->delta_us); }
```
with the following error and ouput:
```
stdin:1:1-34: ERROR: tracepoint not found: xfs:xfs_file_read_done
tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_read_done { @["read"] = hist(args->delta_us); }
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

```

And fix the error.

```
    tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_open_done { @["open"] = hist(args->delta_ns); }
```

[run_bpftrace_prog_with_function_call]:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.

Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

```
	tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_open_done { @["open"] = hist(args->delta_us); }
```

full prompt:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```

traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.

This is your trail 3 out of 3 trails.
Please retry generating the bpftrace program for: traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.
And fix the error.



[run_bpftrace_prog_with_function_call]:  
You should Write a bpftrace program that traces or profile the
following user request: traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.


Below are some simple examples of bpftrace programs:

trace processes calling sleep:
```
kprobe:do_nanosleep { printf("PID %d sleeping...", pid); }
```

count syscalls by process name:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Files opened by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_open { printf("%s %s", comm, str(args->filename)); }
```

Syscall count by program:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Read bytes by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read /args->ret/ { @[comm] = sum(args->ret); }
```

Read size distribution by process:
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_exit_read { @[comm] = hist(args->ret); }
```

Show per-second syscall rates:
```
tracepoint:raw_syscalls:sys_enter { @ = count(); } interval:s:1 { print(@); clear(@); }
```

Trace disk size by process:
```
tracepoint:block:block_rq_issue { printf("%d %s %d", pid, comm, args->bytes); }
```

Count page faults by process
```
software:faults:1 { @[comm] = count(); }
```

Count LLC cache misses by process name and PID (uses PMCs):
```
hardware:cache-misses:1000000 { @[comm, pid] = count(); }
```

Profile user-level stacks at 99 Hertz, for PID 189:
```
profile:hz:99 /pid == 189/ { @[ustack] = count(); }
```

Files opened, for processes in the root cgroup-v2
```
tracepoint:syscalls:sys_enter_openat /cgroup == cgroupid("/sys/fs/cgroup/unified/mycg")/ { printf("%s", str(args->filename)); }
```

tcp connect events with PID and process name
```
kprobe:tcp_connect { printf("connected from pid %d, comm %s", pid, comm); }
```


You can refer to the above examples and hints to
write your own bpftrace program to help user with:

traces XFS reads, writes, opens, and fsyncs, and summarizes their latency as a power-of-2 histogram.

Use a tool provided to execute your bpftrace program.
No explain and no instructions. No extra words of description other 
than bpftrace program. No need to write the bpftrace command, only the program itself.
Make sure the program can be run with bpftrace, keep the eBPF program short and clear
to avoid more mistakes.

Run the bpftrace program
```
 tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_read_done { @["read"] = hist(args->delta_us); }
	tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_write_done { @["write"] = hist(args->delta_us); }
	tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_open_done { @["open"] = hist(args->delta_us); }
	tracepoint:xfs:xfs_file_fsync_done { @["fsync"] = hist(args->delta_us); }
```
